evidence.pdf_reference: the catalyst properties, the Mg 2 in the center of the porphyrin molecule was substituted by Cu 2 .The modified g-Chl-Cu as a photocatalyst exhibited excellent selectivity and activity for CO 2 RR with only C 2 H 6 detected in the GC spectrum (Fig. 6e).The inverted peak corresponded to the un-reacted H 2 O. Fig. 6a also shows the yield for the hydrocarbons on the g-Chl-Cu photocatalysts.It was obvious that the average production rate of C 2 H 6 was 68.23 mol m -2 h -1 .Our photocatalysts were superior to

was observed to increase after photocatalytic reaction through the molecular sieve column and TCD in GC.The O 2 to C 2 H 6 ratio was close to the expected 3.5 : 1 stoichiometry after the 18-hour reaction (Fig. 6d).This confirmed that the water oxidation reaction also occurred on the photocatalyst, which consumed the photo-induced holes to realize sacrificial regent-free CO 2 RR.Furthermore, a 13 CO 2 isotope experiment was employed to directly confirm that the carbon source of the C 2 H 6 product was from

To confirm whether the products were generated through catalysis or decomposition of the photocatalyst itself, a series of control experiments were performed.The photocatalyst film was either irradiated in an enclosed chamber with a N 2 or O 2 atmosphere or was heated to 50 C in a CO 2 atmosphere chamber without light irradiation.No hydrocarbons were detected (Fig. 6a) in all of the experimental conditions after the 18 h reaction, indicating that g-Chl-Cu was very stable under light

of the C 2 H 6 product was from the CO 2 molecules.Only 13 C 2 H 6 was detected when 13 CO 2 and H 2 O were the reactants (Fig. 6f ), thus confirming that C 2 H 6 originated from the CO 2 molecules. chamber was fixed on an on-line vacuum system, which possessed a vacuometer.This on-line vacuum system was connected to a gas chromatography (GC) system by a sample line.The total volume of the chamber and vacuum system was 1455 cm 3 .The photographs of this reaction system are shown in Fig. S1a b. The film with catalyst was loaded into the chamber, and then the chamber was sealed and evacuated before the injection of the reactant gas.An airflow of 99.99 pure CO 2 passed through a de-ionized water

of irradiation. To confirm whether the products were generated through catalysis or decomposition of the photocatalyst itself, a series of control experiments were performed.The photocatalyst film was either irradiated in an enclosed chamber with a N 2 or O 2 atmosphere or was heated to 50 C in a CO 2 atmosphere chamber without light irradiation.No hydrocarbons were detected (Fig. 6a) in all of the experimental conditions after the 18 h reaction, indicating that g-Chl-Cu was very stable under light

reactive intermediates of CH 4 such as CH 2 O (can be detected by TC detectors) and CH 3 OH, were not detected either.This exceptional result suggested that the photocatalytic process described in this work had an outstanding selectivity for C 2 H 6 .Furthermore, we measured the apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of CO 2 RR on the basis of the ferrioxalate actinometer method.The AQE of the g-Chl-Cu samples reached 1.26 at 420 nm and the C 2 H 6 yield was 0.77 after 18 hours of irradiation.
